content.description:
Excellent granite with a fun mix of climbing and in a wonderful location.  

  Climb past two very cool Horizontal cracks (red camalot). Then move left and make thin moves up the face. A long reach or good footwork gains the left slanting flake. Step onto the flake then continue left to a hard to see bolt, pull up to a lower angle slab above the treetops. Five more bolts up the slab (5.9) lead to a three bolt anchor.   

  Two totally different awesome routes packed into one!
content.protection: 10ish bolts to bolt anchor and a red Camalot.
content.location: About 70 feet right of   Sex on the Beach is a steep bolted wall with two horizontal cracks low on it.

content.description: Steep slab climbing at its best, climb past some low cracks and follow the bolts to the anchor.
content.location: Dicky ledge, Walking to the right at the base of the cliff you will come to a shallow rounded groove with a couple of horizontal cracks at the bottom of the route. And a flat stone at the base also. To the left is a bolted route up a low angle slab.

content.description:
I just know this is what everybody is looking for in a rock climb.      Nearly one hundred feet of intense slabbing! 

  After clipping the first bolt of Sex on the Beach break right and step onto a horizontal crack (red Camalot). Now on to the business micro crimp, edge, palm, and whatever else you can do to keep moving upward. Nearing the top the climbing seems to ease some. 

  For the nature of this route I found the clipping stances far less than horrendous. They are actually quite friendly adding to the enjoyability of this steep slab.
content.protection: 11 bolts to chains, optional cam down low.
content.location: Same as Sex on the Beach

content.description:
Just great fun and fine rock!  

  P1. 80, 5.11 Start up a short right facing corner to a stance just below the first bolt. A tricky step off the stance gains an undercling to layback crack up to another stance. From this stance follow bolts past a small overlap up a low angle but extremely thin face/slab ending in a big solution pocket at chains.I found a small mono pocket on the upper face, memorable!  

  P2. 90, 5.10+ From the anchor climb up an easy low angle slab past more solution pockets to the base of a short wall with a few bolts. After pulling over the wall continue up another 40 feet of unprotected 5.0 slab to a blueberry ledge and chains.    

  Both pitches can be linked with minimal rope drag.    Walk off or make two raps with a 60m rope.
content.protection: P1 7 bolts & #2 camalot to Chains. P2 4 bolts to Chains.
content.location: Below and south of The Beach. Approaching from the base several hundred feet right  South America Flake are four bolted routes on a steep face this is the first one. It starts about ten feet left of "Sex On The Beach"

content.description: Â Next bolted line right of Members Only. Hard climbing to the horizontal crack. Sustained climbing past the next three bolts to a reprieve on the right, More intricate climbing leads to a crack that is followed 20ft to chain anchors.
Climb up the bolt line behind the oak tree, thin moves up the steep face gains the slab to the anchors.
content.location: about 30 feet left of Subversive Behavior. You will see a bolt line behind a oak tree.

content.description:
Going to The Beach? 

  From a ledge climb to another ledge, step right then boulder up past a few bolts to The Beach.
content.protection: 7 bolts to an eye bolt, another route, or a belay on the right, or if you come up with something else that's impressive.
content.location: The furthest right bolted route before Tom and Jay's Climb, below the beach.

content.description: Fantastic sustained climbing! Some super fun and challenging slab routes can be found here, often with an interesting horizontal crack near the base. Great classic lines with interesting cruxes, a wonderful setting, and the length to back them up. These 80 to 100+ ft routes are mostly sport bolted with sometimes optional (I guess it is always optional) or required gear in places.
